The Project is a follow-on to the ongoing Plantation Reform Project 
(ongoing project), which was designed to transfer ownership of the 
plantation  sector  through  divestment  of  the  23  regional  plantation 
companies  (RPCs).  The  Project  will  maintain  the  momentum  for 
the reform process to create an enabling environment that will put 
RPCs  on  a  sound  financial  footing  for  long-term  sustainability 
without external assistance. This development will improve RPCs’ 
profitability  and  enable  them  to  provide  the  estate  workers  with 
better working and living conditions, which are currently very poor. 
The  Project  will  provide  long-term  financing  to  meet  RPCs’ 
investment  needs.  A  plantation  fund  (PF)  will  be  established  to 
invest  in  equity  and  quasi-equity  instruments  of  RPCs  as  an 
alternative  to  traditional  collateral-based  lending.  The  Project  will 
address  the  estate  workers’  poor  working,  living,  and  social 
conditions  through  a  social  component  that  includes  amenities  in 
the  residential  and  work  areas,  and  empowerment  of  the  workers 
through 
institutions,  awareness 
programs,  and  training.  Attention  will  be  paid  to  marketing 
initiatives  and  institutional  strengthening  to  address  the  current 
overly regulated marketing of tea and to give RPCs easier access 
to export markets. 
 
With  20  RPCs  divested  under  the  ongoing  project,  the  sector’s 
performance  has  improved  in  terms  of  yields,  production,  and 
profitability. However, the sector is still faced with high production 
cost and low profitability because of the legacy of neglect and poor 
management  during  nationalization.  Due 
the  excessive

not  diversified  sufficiently  to  broaden  its  profit  base.  The  banking 
system provides no long-term financing for long-term investments. 
The  sector  also  faces  a  looming  labor  shortage  because  of  out-

The Project aims to (i) enhance the profitability of the sector, and 
(ii) improve the living and working conditions of the estate workers. 
The  project  area  covers  15  districts  where  RPC  estates  are

coconuts;  crop  and  noncrop  diversification;  factory  consolidation 
and automation; and effluent treatment plants and marketing; (ii) a 
social  and  environmental  component  to  cover  self-help  housing 
and  amenities,  social  awareness  programs,  strengthening  of 
estate-level institutions, and land surveys to enhance planning and 
land  use;    (iii)  marketing  initiatives  through  product  research  and 
development;  fair  trade  labeling;  and  support  for  compliance  with 
requirements  of  ethical  trade;  and  (iv)  institutional  strengthening 
through support for an industry umbrella body, consulting services, 
and training and development of outgrower models. The Project is 
expected to replant and infill 1,750 hectares (ha) and 2,370 ha of 
tea,  replant  3,750  ha  of  rubber,  plant  2,500  ha  of  oil  palm  and 
10,000  ha  of  forest  plantation,  and  establish  five  marketing 
alliances.  The  Project  will  provide  housing  loans  to  6,000  estate 
workers, reroof 11,000 line rooms and provide welfare facilities and 
amenities in the workplace. 
 
The total project cost is estimated at $114.4 million equivalent, with 
$34.4  million  (30%)  in  foreign  exchange  and  $80.0  million  (70%) 
equivalent in local currency.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

 
A. 
 
2. 
The tree crop (tea, rubber, and coconuts) sector contributes 15.6% of agriculture gross 
domestic product (GDP) and 3% of total GDP. About 40% of the tea and rubber land is in the 
hands  of  the  regional  plantation  companies  (RPCs),  with  the  balance  in  the  hands  of 
smallholders,2 whereas only about 2% of coconut land is in the hands of RPCs. The plantation 
sector accounts for 19% of foreign earnings and employs 265,000 workers.  
 
3. 
The plantation sector has underperformed since nationalization in the 1970s when 500 
tea  and  rubber  estates  and  400  factories  were  put  under  the  management  of  two  state 
plantation  corporations:  Janatha  Estate  Development  Board  (JEDB)  and  Sri  Lanka  State 
Plantation  Corporation  (SLSPC).  Underperformance  is  reflected  in  low  productivity  relative  to 
that  in  other  countries.  The  current  yields  for  tea  (1,500  kilograms/hectare  [kg/ha])  and  rubber 
(900  kg/ha)  are  far  below  those  of  other  producing  countries  such  as  India  (1,700  kg/ha)  and 
Kenya (2,200 kg/ha) for tea, and Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand (1,400 kg/ha) for rubber.  
 
B. 
 
4. 
The  poor  performance  of  the  sector  is  attributed  to  restrictive  regulations  and 
inappropriate  fiscal  policies  that  have  eroded  the  competitive  advantage.3  The  project 
framework  is  in  Appendix  1.    The  lessons  learned  from  past  projects  (Appendix  2)  show  that 
providing investment costs is not enough. Policy issues must also be addressed. In supporting 
the state corporations, past projects had prolonged state ownership, promoted inefficiency, and 
contributed  to  the  sector’s  decline.  As  a  result,  the  two  state  plantation  corporations  incurred 
huge losses and were a drain on the state coffers.  
 
Restructuring took place in 1992 when 450 estates were formed into 22 RPCs4 and their

RPCs.  Other  reforms  included  liberalization  of  direct  tea  exports,  restructuring  of  JEDB  and 
SLSPC, and reconstitution of the boards of Tea Research Institute (TRI), Sri Lanka Tea Board

6. 
With  divestment  and  assistance  under  the  ongoing  project,  the  RPCs'  tea  yields  have 
increased 3% while rubber yield has stabilized at about 900 kg/ha. The sector’s profitability has 
improved significantly: RPCs’ collective losses of SLRs1.7 billion in 1993 turned into collective 
profits of SLRS1.6 billion in 2000, thus relieving the State Treasury from supporting the sector. 
The  housing  improvement  program  of  the  ongoing  project  has  benefited  an  estimated  25%  of 
workers  in  terms  of  improved  living  conditions,  and  the  training  program  has  benefited  up  to 
30% of the workers. In addition, the ongoing project brought about an important change in the 
management attitude toward the workers. 
 
Nevertheless, the profitability of the plantation sector is low because of low productivity 
7. 
and  high  production  cost,  which  are  in  turn  due  to  the  poor  condition  of  the  estates  and 
overaged  plantings  (Appendixes  3  and  4).  The  mixed  financial  positions  of  RPCs  (seven 
financially  strong,  nine  moderate,  and  four  weak)  are  partly  attributable  to  the  inherent 
properties of the estates and partly to RPCs’ vulnerability to fluctuations in international prices 
because  they  remain  producers  of  primary  commodities.  The  limited  diversification  and 
downstream activities stem partly from lack of technical expertise within RPCs and partly from 
the  restrictive  regulations  on  import  of  planting  materials  and  direct  tea  exports.  Although 
producers can directly export 50% of their bulk tea production, the regulations imposed by SLTB 
effectively enforce marketing through auction.   
 
8. 
The sector’s development is also constrained by lack of long-term funds in the banking 
sector to finance long-gestation investments. Lending by some commercial banks has limits on 
exposure to the sector. Besides, some RPCs are considered no longer creditworthy because of 
their weak financial position. The extraction of management fees by parent companies7 and the 
escalation of lease rental payments to the Government also threaten to undermine the financial 
position of RPCs.  The Government is presently negotiating with RPCs to cap management fees 
and  revise  the  lease  rental  payments  on  a  case-by-case  basis.  A  looming  labor  shortage 
caused by out-migration and reluctance of the youth to work on the estates also constrains the 
development of the sector. The stigma attached to estate employment is associated with poor 
living environment, harsh working conditions, and traditional top-down management style.  
 
9.  
To  improve  profitability  and  provide  strategic  direction  for  the  tea  industry,  which 
contributes 12.6% of the total export earnings, the ongoing project undertook a strategy study 
for the tea sector. The study concluded that the global over supply of tea will continue to exert a 
downward  pressure  on  tea  prices.  This,  coupled  with  increasing  production  cost,  will  render  a 
significant proportion of Sri Lanka’s tea industry unprofitable in the near future. To ensure long-

assistance  is  needed  to  put  in  place  mechanisms  to  enable  RPCs  to  build  up  their  capital 
reserve and to ensure transparency in their operations. While the ultimate objective is to enable 
RPCs to provide employment terms comparable to those in other sectors, the immediate poor 
conditions  of  the  estate  workers  will  need  to  be  addressed.  Although  the  majority  of  the 
households  have  more  than  one  income  earner  and  the  estate  family's  income  is  higher  than 
that  of  nonestate  rural  families,  the  standard  of  living  in  the  estate  sector  is  lower  than  that  in 
other sectors of the economy. This is indicated by the lower literacy rates, higher school dropout 
rates, and negative savings rates. Mismanagement of household finances and alcoholism keep 
estate households in the lower strata of Sri Lankan society. 
 
As  RPCs  are  collectively  the  largest  net  foreign  exchange  earner  and  employer,

Environmental Initiatives  

 
21. 
Land  use  and  cover  change  are  important  features  of  development  in  plantations.  A 
better understanding of land use transformations should assist in developing more appropriate 
land use systems, not only to help degraded lands but also to increase profitability. Current land 
use and management planning on the estates are not efficient for lack of detailed land and soil 
surveys, including the exact areas and location of fields, infrastructure, property boundaries, and 
soil  and  terrain  types.  The  Project  will  assist  RPCs  to  carry  out  these  critical  surveys  using  a 
geographic information system (GIS) and geographic positioning system (GPS) to clearly define 
the resource base to allow better strategic planning in land use (such as fertilizer and pesticide 
use,  and  appropriate  vegetative  cover)  and,  in  the  process,  mitigate  the  deterioration  and 
erosion of the soil. Subsequent surveys will cover all holdings of RPCs, estates and areas for 
subleasing. The surveys will be conducted to standards applied by professional agencies in Sri 
Lanka utilizing GPS/GIS. Land surveys will cover an area of 190,000 ha.

profitability and maximize shareholder value.

the  environmental  practices  of  the  estates.  The  Project  seeks  to  apply  the  concept  of  fair  and

60.

higher income for the workers although the impact will differ between male and female workers.

workers’  conditions  will  be  disbursement  of  housing  loans,  factory  and  field  rest  rooms

In  the  third  year,  ADB,  MPI,  PIU,  and  the  apex  body  will  carry  out  a  comprehensive 
midterm  review  of  all  aspects  of  the  Project:  implementation  progress,  appropriateness  of  the 
project  design,  and  the  implementation  arrangements.  The  review  will  focus  on  the  policy 
reforms to assess the relevance and impact of these reforms. Necessary adjustments in project 
scope,  design,  and  implementation  arrangements  will  be  made  based  on  the  findings.  In 
addition, an environmental audit will review the progress of self-assessment of compliance with 
standards, benefits from additional market access, and applications of the information gathered. 
 

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
63. 
Quantifiable benefits accrue from the subprojects of the investment component. At peak 
production,  the  Project  will  yield  an  incremental  production  of  approximately  5,000  tons  of  tea 
and 7,900 tons of rubber valued at $7 million and $1.5 million respectively. Crop diversification 
activities,  such  as  oil  palm,  pepper,  and  coffee,  are  expected  to  yield  an  export  value  of  $2.8 
million  per  annum.  Successful  operation  of  the  marketing  alliances  will  yield  an  incremental 
annual  income  of  $10  million.  Other  quantifiable  benefits  are  reduced  production  cost  from 
factory  rationalization  and  automation,  and  savings  in  energy  costs  from  rehabilitated  mini-
hydropower stations. The opportunities for value addition, direct sales, enhanced buyer-friendly 
processes,  and  improved  logistics  emanating  from  the  marketing  initiatives  will  give  rise  to 
higher profit margins and more stable revenues for RPCs. The financial and economic analyses 
of  the  potential  subprojects  show  that  they  have  financial  internal  rate  of  returns  (FIRRs)  and 
economic internal rate of returns (EIRR) above the real onlending rate and opportunity cost of 
capital  (Appendix  11).  The  RPCs’  scheduled  investment  programs  indicate  an  overall  project 
FIRR  of  14%  and  EIRR  of  16%.  Analysis  of  two  sample  RPCs  indicates  that  the  Project  will 

 

  18 

 

improve their cash flows and long-term profitability, and that the impact is greater on the RPC 
that  is  financially  weaker.  The  nonquantifiable  benefits  of  the  investment  component  include 
increased ability of RPCs to pay higher wages and provide better working and living conditions 
for the workers. This will make estate employment attractive to the youth, and thus contribute to 
the reduction in urban drift and rural unemployment.  
 
64. 
The social component has many nonquantifiable benefits. Overall, it will strengthen the 
capacity of the estate population to improve their lives and to integrate into the mainstream of 
society.  It  will  also  enable  both  the  workers  and  RPCs  to  move  away  from  the  captive  labor 
model  of  the  past  toward  a  more  modern  management  system.  The  self-help  housing  loan 
scheme  will  improve  the  physical  well-being  of  the  workers,  raise  their  self-esteem  and  the 
social  image  of  plantation  employment,  leading  to  reduced  voluntary  unemployment  and  out-
migration.  House  ownership  and  its  related  responsibility  will  provide  the  beneficiaries  with 
motivation for optimizing the use of funds. The improved line rooms will have a great impact on 
women who have to bear the effects of inferior living conditions because they are responsible 
for all domestic work and have to deal with the consequence of poor living conditions, including 
illness in the family. Strengthening EWHCS and other estate-level institutions will empower the 
workers, especially women. 
 
65. 
The  social  awareness  programs  aim  to  increase  gender  awareness  and  reduce  the 
incidence  of  alcoholism  and  worker-management  conflicts.  The  anti-alcohol  programs  will 
reduce domestic violence and indebtedness in the short term. In the long term, they will improve 
labor outturn and workers’ productivity, indirectly reduce the school dropout rate. The household 
cash management training will help reduce the incidence of indebtedness and raise the workers’ 
disposable  income  and  savings,  thus  reducing  their  vulnerability.  Playgrounds  and  social 
development  centers  within  the  estates  will  provide  a  better  sociocultural  environment,  and 
sports  activities  will  assist  in  integrating  workers  from  different  ethnic  groups  and  castes,  in 
addition  to  reducing  boredom  and  alcohol  abuse.  The  use  of  ergonomic  and  protective  work 
equipment and provision of facilities in the residential and work areas will increase the workers' 
productivity and enhance their well-being. Replicating the five S and quality circles system will 
bring  about  greater  job  satisfaction  for  workers  and  reduced  conflict  with  the  management, 
resulting in better labor utilization and increased productivity. In view of the different ethnic origin 
of  management  and  workers,  an  orientation  program  for  the  management  to  increase 
understanding of the quality circle and participatory management systems will improve industrial 
relations and social integration of the excluded Tamil communities. 
 
The Project will have positive impacts on the environment (Appendix 12). The land-use 
66. 
surveys  will  heighten  people's  awareness  of  the  role  of  land  capability  and  productivity.  This, 
coupled  with  sound  forest  management,  will  address  and  reduce  the  serious  problem  of  soil 
erosion  and  degradation  as  well  as  protect  the  watersheds.  Installing  and  rehabilitating  of 
pollution control structures, and training in their operation and maintenance in existing and new 
rubber factories will improve the water quality of rivers and streams in the project area. 
 
67. 
RPCs,  as  commodity  producers,  are  faced  with  the  risk  of  price  fluctuations  in  the 
international market. This risk is compounded by RPCs’ inability to make strategic investments 
to  realize  improvements  in  profitability  and  financial  position.  This  risk  is  mitigated  to  a  great 
extent with training in strategic planning and the requirement of strategic business plans when 
submitting  subloan  applications  to  PFIs.  There  is  a  risk  that  the  social  development  programs 
may  not  yield  the  envisaged  benefits  because  of  lack  of  commitment  by  RPCs  and  lack  of 
cooperation from the workers unions. Continuous consultation with RPCs and workers as well 
as  incorporation  of  worker  participatory  procedures  will  mitigate  the  risk.  Lack  of  Government

commitment to the reforms and the industry umbrella body will nullify the efforts to liberalize tea 
marketing and get all stakeholders’ commitment to transform the plantation sector. To mitigate 
this risk, the Project provides for continuous policy dialogue.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 

The Plantation Sector 

 
A. 
 
The tree crop (tea, rubber and coconuts) sector contributes 15.6% of agriculture's gross 
1. 
domestic product (GDP) and 3% of total GDP. About 40% of the tea and rubber land are in the 
plantation sector, with the balance in the hands of smallholders. The plantation sector accounts 
for 19% of foreign earnings and employs 290,000 workers.  
 
2. 
The  plantation  sector  was  nationalized  following  land  reform  in  1972  when  land 
ownership  was  restricted  to  20  hectares  (ha).  About  500  tea,  rubber,  and  coconut  estates 
together  with  400  tea  and  rubber  factories  were  nationalized  and  vested  in  two  state 
corporations, the Janatha Estate Development Board (JEDB) and the Sri Lanka State Plantation 
Corporation  (SLSPC).  The  threat  of  nationalization  prior  to  its  occurrence  had  discouraged 
investments, and the nationalized estates were in a poor state. Weak management during state 
ownership  as  well  as  restrictive  regulations  and  inappropriate  fiscal  policies  undermined  the 
comparative competitiveness of the sector and resulted in JEDB and SLSPC turning in annual 
losses for most of the period up to 1992. The decision was taken to restructure the plantations 
because  the  losses  were  a  drain  on  the  state  coffers.  The  450  estates  were  formed  into  22 
regional  plantation  companies  (RPCs),1  which  were  contracted  out  to  private  management 
companies  (MCs)  for  management  on  5-year  terms.  This  was  not  workable  as  the  5-year 
contracts were too short for the MCs to invest in long-term development. 
 
Divestment  of  the  RPCs  began  in  1995  with  support  from  the  ongoing  project,2  which 
3. 
was  designed  to  (i)  support  the  policy  and  institutional  reforms  in  the  sector,  and  (ii)  provide 
long-term  funds  to  eligible  RPCs  through  the  commercial  banks.3  The  main  policy  reform 
agenda was the divestment of the 23 RPCs. Other policy reforms included raising the ceiling of 
direct  exports  by  tea  producers  to  50%  of  production;  reconstitution  of  the  boards  of  related 
institutions  (Tea  Research  Institute,  Sri  Lanka  Tea  Board,  National  Institute  of  Plantation 
Management,  Tea  Smallholdings  Development  Authority,  Rubber  Research  Institute  and 
Coconut Research Institute); and restructuring of the remaining estates managed by JEDB and 
SLSPC.  The  project  components  were  (i)  a  credit  component  to  provide  investment  funds  to 
eligible  RPCs;  and  (ii)  a  noncredit  component  for  reforestation  of  watersheds,  improvement  of 
workers housing, institutional strengthening, and project management.  
 
4. 
The main policy agenda was largely accomplished with 20 of the RPCs divested of. Two 
(Chilaw and Kurunegala Plantation Ltd.) remained in private management, and one (Elkaduwa

The  project  achievements  of  replanting/infilling/upkeep  of  6,903  ha  tea  and  20,451  ha

tea industry. The study concluded that, with the higher growth in supply relative to demand, tea 
prices would remain low and the plantation sector would need to go downstream to capture a 
greater  margin  of  the  retail  tea  trade.  The  study  recommended  measures  to  support  the

product research and development, and self-regulation through an industry umbrella body. 
 
6. 
While  the  targets  were  exceeded  and  an  estimated  25%  of  worker  families  benefited 
from the reroofing scheme, it is still too early to evaluate the impact of the ongoing project. The 
RPCs’  tea  yield  has  increased  3%  and  rubber  yield  has  stabilized.  Collectively,  the  RPCs’ 
profitability  has  improved  significantly  from  a  loss  of  SLRs  1.7  billion  in  1993  to  a  profit  of 
SLRs1.6 billion in 2000 (Table A3). Nevertheless, the financial positions of RPCs are still mixed, 
with  seven  rated  as  strong,  nine  as  moderate,  and  four  as  weak.  Financial  performance 
underscores the problems and constraints faced by the plantation sector that has just made a 
transition from state ownership to private ownership.  
 
B. 
 
7. 
Despite  gains  made  in  yields  after  privatization,  the  plantation  sector  still  faces  low 
productivity.  The  sector’s  average  tea  yield  of  1,500  kg/ha  is  much  lower  than  that  of  the 
smallholder sector (2,200 kg/ha) and other tea producing countries such as India (1,700 kg/ha) 
and Kenya (2,200 kg/ha). Likewise, the rubber yield of 900 kg/ha is below the average of about 
1,400 kg/ha in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Many factors account for the low yields. The 
threat of nationalization had discouraged investments. Although investments were subsequently 
made during state ownership and, then after divestment, these investments were far less than 
the  requirements.  Besides,  they  did  not  produce  the  expected  benefits  because  of  weak 
management during state ownership. In addition, during state ownership the sector was isolated 
from  development  in  other  countries  and  no  new  technology  had  been  introduced  to  improve 
productivity  and  efficiency.  Restrictive  regulations  and  excessive  taxes  on  the  sector  further 
undermined  its  competitiveness.  These  factors  have  made  Sri  Lanka  a  high-cost  producer  of 
these commodities with consequent low profitability in the sector. 
 
The sector remains vulnerable to fluctuations in the international prices of tea and rubber 
8. 
and will be increasingly under pressure with the current trend of higher supply growth vis-à-vis 
demand in the world market. At the same time, RPCs remain as primary producers, unable to 
capture a bigger margin of the increasing retail trade value. This is especially true for tea, where 
95%  of  production  continues  to  be  sold  in  the  tea  auction.  Although  the  auction  is  seen  as  a 
transparent  means  of  price  determination  and  has  the  advantage  of  a  wide  presence  of 
international  buyers,  there  is  growing  dissatisfaction  on  how  the  auction  is  currently  operated. 
Although  the  Government  has  raised  the  ceiling  on  direct  tea  exports  by  producers  to  50% 
under the ongoing project, direct exports are still very difficult in reality because tea traders and 
exporters  actively  discourage  it.  With  their  stronger  influence  with  the  Sri  Lanka  Tea  Board 
(SLTB), the tea traders have effectively lobbied for a single-channel marketing system through 
the  auction.  The  rules  and  regulations  imposed  by  SLTB  also  tend  to  favor  sales  through  the 
auction. Other reasons for RPCs’ inability to go into direct exports include their lack of marketing 
expertise, lack of contact with buyers, and inability to offer appropriate lot sizes. The scenario is 
different  for  rubber  where  regulations  on  marketing  are  less  and  linkages  between  producers

9. 
The vulnerability of RPCs to fluctuations in international prices of tea and rubber reflects 
their  concentration  on  these  two  core  crops.  The  plantation  sector  has  traditionally  been 
reluctant  to  consider  enterprise  diversification  seriously.  With  the  present  trend  of  commodity 
prices, RPCs are beginning to realize the importance of diversification to reduce dependence on 
one  or  two  crops  and  to  optimize  land  use.  Nine  RPCs  have  diversified  into  crops  other  than 
forestry, several are leasing land to other firms for diversification, and two are negotiating joint 
ventures  for  crop  and  noncrop  diversification.  But  the  main  constraint  to  diversification  is  the 
absence  of  the  requisite  managerial,  technical,  and  marketing  skills.  Other  constraints  are  the 
restrictive  phytosanitary  regulations  for  import  of  improved  planting  materials,  lack  of 
appropriate research and development on key crops, and high duties on agribusiness inputs.   
 
10. 
Investments  to  improve  the  productivity  of  core  activities  as  well  as  diversification  into 
other  crop  and  noncrop  activities  assume  an  available  supply  of  cheap  labor  to  work  on  the 
estates.  This  is  no  longer  the  case,  as  economic  diversification  in  the  country  and  education 
have opened up employment opportunities in other sectors. The challenge to RPCs is to retain 
the  workers  with  a  competitive  remuneration  package  while  grappling  with  issues  of  low 
profitability  and  commercial  viability.  Wages  in  the  plantation  sector  are  below  those  in  other 
sectors  although  this  is  compensated  somewhat  by  the  housing  and  other  benefits  that 
plantations  historically  provided.  However,  the  standard  of  living  in  the  estate  sector  is  lower 
than that in other sectors. In fact, 80% of the housing is in the form of barracks-type line rooms 
that are overcrowded, badly ventilated, badly lighted, with leaky roofs and inadequate sanitary 
facilities. The poor living conditions and the past top-down management approach have given a 
stigma  to  estate  employment.  The  estate  workers  are  mainly  descendants  of  migrant  laborers 
from  India  and  their  legacy  of  living  in  enclaves  in  the  estates  has  isolated  them  from 
mainstream  society.  Statistics  indicate  that  the  estate  sector  has  a  high  incidence  of  school 
dropouts, youth unemployment, alcoholism, and indebtedness. It is therefore not surprising that 
labor  shortage  looms  because  estate  youth  prefer  employment  outside  the  estates.  The 
importance  of  good  housing  and  working  conditions  was  stressed  during  the  participatory 
workshops  and  some  RPCs  have  recognized  the  impact  of  living  and  working  conditions  on 
productivity. 
  
11. 
Investments to improve the productivity of the sector require long-term financing as the 
enterprises  have  a  long  gestation  period.  However,  long-term  funds  are  not  available  in  the 
banking  system.  In  addition,  the  interest  rates  are  distorted  by  Treasury  bond  rates  so  that 
returns  from  investments  do  not  match  the  interest  rates.  The  problem  of  availability  of  long-
term funds was alleviated somewhat by the ongoing project but the loan proceeds for the credit 
line has been fully utilized. A revolving fund, established to plough back the repayments into the 
sector,  will  address  this  funding  problem  somewhat.  However,  some  commercial  banks  have 
indicated that they have reached their limits in exposure to the plantation sector and would not 
be  able  to  finance  the  sector  further  even  if  funds  were  available.  At  the  same  time,  the  poor 
financial position of some RPCs has rendered them uncreditworthy in the eyes of the banks.  
 
12.

privatization  procedures  were  changed  midstream  to  push  up  the  share  prices  of  RPCs,  and 
some  parent  companies  had  taken  loans  to  pay  for  the  shares.  The  parent  companies  then

13. 
The  tree  crop  sector  has  received  considerable  assistance  from  aid  agencies,  with  the 
World  Bank  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  being  the  main  sources.  ADB  has  given 
eight loans to the plantation sector since 1968 (Appendix 2), but the development of the sector 
was suppressed by inappropriate regulations and fiscal policies.5 The earlier projects provided 
the  funds  for  development  but  did  not  address  the  issue  of  policy  environment.  In  providing 
assistance  to  the  state  corporations,  the  past  projects  prolonged  state  ownership  and 
contributed to the inefficiency and decline of the sector. It was therefore recommended that ADB 
continue to give emphasis on assistance for reforms that will ensure market-driven adjustments 
and  sustainability  of  the  sector.  Reforms  started  under  the  Second  Program  Loan  with  the 
reduction in cess and elimination of export duties. The ongoing project further addresses policy 
issues through privatization and institutional reforms. 
 
14. 
The implementation of the ongoing project has provided some useful lessons. The major 
lesson  is  that  the  Government  should  maintain  a  consistent  and  well  thought-out  policy  to 
achieve the desired benefits. The privatization of RPCs aimed to improve profitability by putting 
management  decisions  with  the  private  sector.  However,  the  policy  was  not  followed  through 
because of political intervention; three RPCs were not divested and no progress took place in 
restructuring JEDB and SLSPC.  
 
15. 
Another lesson is the difficulty of policy reform, given the vested interest of the different 
segments of the industry. Although the Government raised the ceiling for direct exports to 50%, 
SLTB continues to impose restrictions that favor single-channel marketing through the auction 
because  of  the  stronger  influence  of  the  tea  buyers.  Likewise,  the  restrictions  on  forestry  and 
other activities restrained RPCs’ efforts to diversify from their core activities. Vested interest and 
political  interference  also  affected  the  institutional  reforms  that  were  aimed  at  improving  the 
effectiveness of the related institutions.  
 
16. 
The  ongoing  project  also  demonstrates  that  the  legacy  of  public  ownership  remains  in 
the management of the divested RPCs. RPCs still lack expertise in marketing and diversification 
activities.  In  many  cases,  investments  in  field  and  factory  development  were  carried  out  as  a 
matter  of  habit  and  not  as  a  result  of  strategic  business  planning.  The  results  are  suboptimal 
investments and the slow pace of diversification to broaden the profit base.  
 
Lastly, the ongoing project addressed the immediate need for reroofing of the workers'

their  social  status.  Experience  from  the  Dutch-financed  Plantation  Development  Support

THE PLANTATION FUND 

The Need for the Plantation Fund  

 
A. 
 
The banking sector in Sri Lanka lacks long-term funds, and lending is based on collateral 
1. 
rather  than  on  enterprise  viability.  Financing  problems  arise  in  the  plantation  sector  where  the 
financial  health  of  some  regional  plantation  company  (RPCs)  is  deteriorating  while  their  debt-
bearing  capacity  has  reached  the  upper  limits.  At  the  same  time,  the  participating  financial 
institutions  (PFIs)  have  indicated  that  their  exposure  to  the  plantation  sector  has  reached  the 
ceiling. The implication is that the PFIs may not be in a position to meet the credit demands of 
RPCs even though external funding is available. As availability of long-term funds is critical for 
replanting,  product  development,  and  diversification  in  the  plantation  sector,  other  means  of 
financing must be explored. An alternative is to establish a plantation fund (PF) that will provide 
direct funding in terms of equity and quasi-equity instruments (including direct equity, preference 
shares, and convertible bonds). Thus, the PF will complement the PFIs in financing the sector 
and also help to move the sector toward using the capital markets.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  main  objective  of  the  PF  is  to  provide  medium-  and  long-term  funding  to  eligible 
RPCs  to  strengthen  their  capital  structure.  This  will  increase  the  shareholder  value  in  the 
plantation sector. The second objective is to instill financial discipline in the RPCs through the 
use of convertible debt instruments that enable the PF to convert debt into equity and effect a 
change in the equity structure of RPCs.

Proposed Structure  

C. 
 
3. 
The  decision  on  the  structure  of  the  PF  considered  a  company  and  a  trust.  The 
advantages of a company are that (i) its legal status is more permanent; (ii) it can legally take 
charge over collateral offered by the borrower and enforce it more effectively if the need arises; 
(iii) it has tax benefits, as dividends from investments in RPCs would be tax-free; (iv) it can more 
easily  establish  its  name  in  the  marketplace  and  lend  itself  to  eventual  privatization;  and  (v)  it 
has  easier  access  to  capital  markets.  The  advantages  of  a  trust  are  that  (i)  it  is  set  up  for  a 
special  purpose  and  the  trustees  are  responsible  for  safeguarding  its  interests;  (ii)  its 
beneficiaries  are  its  owners;  (iii)  its  structure  is  more  result-oriented  and  does  not  permit 
interference from the Government; (iv) it is tax-free as long as all profits are distributed and self-
liquidating;  and  (v)  consensus  building  on  the  board  of  trustees  is  much  easier  with  the 
participation from all sectors. 
 
4. 
In view of the objective of the PF, a trust was preferred as it gives operational flexibility 
and independence to the fund manager to achieve the desired level of performance. The board 
of  trustees  will  comprise  eight  trustees  from  various  sectors  of  the  economy:  (i)  one  from 
Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  (ii)  one  from  Ministry  of  Plantation  Industries  (MPI),  (iii)  three  from 
RPCs  on  a  2-year  rotation,  (iv)  one  from  the  Planters’  Association  (PA),  and  (v)  two  from  the 
banking sector on a 2-year rotation basis.

selecting  the  fund  manager  will  include  (i)  alliance  with  an  international  fund  management

A.    Historical Background  
 
The  estate  workers  are  predominantly  Tamils  of  Indian  origin  and  have  worked  for 
1. 
generations  in  the  plantations  of  Sri  Lanka.  From  the  beginning  of  the  first  labor  migrations  in 
the 1830s until around 1900, the estate resident worker population was not permanent and this 
fact  was  reflected  in  the  housing  and  living  environment.  The  turn  of  the  century  was 
characterized by a willingness of immigrant workers to adopt the estate as a more permanent 
home. A cholera epidemic in the mid-1860s had a serious impact on the supply of labor and led 
to the Medical Wants and Diseases Ordinances that empowered the Director of Health Services 
to  prescribe  the  specification  of  the  workers’  line  housing,  including  size,  location,  materials 
used, and sanitary standards. The result was the standardized housing model with its uniform 
line rooms located in pockets around the estates. With the nationalization of the plantations, the 
Janatha  Estates  Development  Board  and  the  Sri  Lanka  State  Plantations  Corporation 
established  social  development  divisions  (SDDs)  to  address  the  welfare  requirements  of  the 
plantation  workers  in  housing  infrastructure  and  health.  After  privatization,  the  Plantation 
Housing  and  Social  Welfare  Trust  (PHSWT)  was  established  to  assume  the  role  of  SDDs  to 
implement worker welfare programs with the participation of the government, trade unions, and 
the regional plantation companies (RPCs).1  
 
B.  

Socioeconomic Profile of the Estate Workers 
 
2. 
From  a  socioeconomic  point  of  view,  the  estate  workers  are  a  uniform  group.  The 
differentiations within the communities depend on the geographic distribution. Estate workers in 
the low country are more closely integrated with the estate’s peripheral environment. Workers in 
the  up  country  are  more  isolated  and  tend  to  look  inward  toward  their  own  community  for 
support.  This  attitude  is  also  reflected  in  their  aspirations.  Workers  in  the  low  elevations  are 
more  prepared  to  work  outside  the  estate  and  even  migrate  to  the  towns,  and  their  housing 
preferences  are  for  detached  units  with  a  high  degree  of  privacy.  On  the  other  hand,  the  up-
country workers prefer to remain on the estate if a desirable living environment is provided, but 
their offspring prefer other forms of employment off the estates.  
 
3. 
The living conditions on the estates are inferior to those in other sectors of the economy 
(Table A7). Availability of good sanitation facilities and electricity is low, as is the availability of 
household  assets.  Barrack-type  or  line  room  housing  still  accounts  for  70-80%  of  all  estate 
houses.  The  majority  of  the  households  have  one  room.  The  living  environment  is  the  most 
important issue for the workers. Improving the existing housing model, as carried out in the past, 
no longer meets their aspirations. The workers are looking beyond such short-term solutions. 
 
The  estate  sector  has  the  lowest  unemployment  rate  in  the  country  because  of  the 
4.

The majority of the educated youth are expressing aversion to plantation work, and their parents 
wish to see their children working outside the estate. The quest of about 169,500 people for out-

nonestate jobs occurs mainly in the lowlands or where there are other work opportunities. As a 
result, RPCs' depend on an increasingly small pool of estate labor and in the future will have to 
deal  with  a  permanent  shortage  of  labor  if  estate  employment  is  not  made  more  attractive.
